ratings.comment: Luke is probably the worst professor I've had at college. Lectures were dull, confusing, and he frequently made mistakes and would mumble through the material. On three out of the four tests, there was material that was literally never covered in lecture or discussion. The only saving grace was my TA, so hope for a great one if you have Luke.

No. Just no. Luke seems like a genuinely nice guy, and is available for help, but taking his class will decimate any chance you had at learning mechanics. Homework and discussion problems are simple, exam problems are impossible. He doesn't seem to care about the discrepancy, or teaching in general. Avoid at all costs! Worst professor I've had.

The lectures were confusing and didn't help me understand the material.  The book was also unhelpful.  The exams for this class were extremely difficult and were not similar to example problems in class or during discussion.  While Luke's heart seems in the right place, I would not recommend this professor to others.

The textbook is very hard if trying to read them through; Mostly it explain how to get the formulas, but not how to use them.  For the professor, he mainly explain 1,how to get the formula shortly 2, use more (and difficult)examples; but still not enough.  Then in the discussion we do the problems. I'd say it's a difficult course, but luke is fine.

His lectures are sometimes hard to follow, but if you ask him to slow down he will take the time to explain more in-depth. I highly recommend going in to office hours. He is really helpful one-on-one.

If you are a bio type major or have basic calc knowledge you are in for your worst nightmare. Expects you 2 know in depth calc w/o teaching it and your grade is completely dependent on it. Lectures don't (do anything) prep you for exams/HW. If you are not a math or engineering major, you are in for a miserable time. Avoid. I can't stress it enough

Awful. He does not know how to teach at all and the exams test more on your ability to do calculus other than understand physics. His grading system is horrible. Exams are very difficult, but manageable if you study 10 hours every day.

Very difficult exams, they didn't follow lectures well at all. He was a first time professor so he didn't really grasp the whole teaching part. You really have to do well on exams, there is no other way to get a decent grade since homework's and quizzes are all curved and average is a B even if it is a 95%

I can see why if you were not a physics, engineering, or math student, you would not like the difficulty of the material of this class. Even though im an engineering student, I could only get into this lecture, he was a hard professor, but I am glad he was, so now I feel more prepared for my future major related classes.

He has with very difficult exams that aren't plug and chug, they require in depth thought but if you go to office hours, he will teach you how to go about this problem solving process. His lectures are fine but usually have some mistakes but they are usually minor. One on one, h's extremely helpful and office hours is the way I did well.

To be honest, he doesn't teach that well but he does FORCE you to learn a LOT of physics. I know SOO much BUT I'm going to get a bad  grade (BC)because gruesome tests. I currently would not recommend him, unless a very generous curve is given(~3.3 avg) so the energy/stress required for the class pays off. It was a crazy semester to say the least...

One of the worst classes I've taken. He's intelligent, but not capable of passing that knowledge to students. He used too many equations that is became confusing. The exams were impossible (both too long and too difficult) with really low averages. This class doesn't have multi-variable calculus as a pre-req, but you definitely need to know it.

Basically, all he did was hand us equations and say solve, all while trying to teach us multi variable calculus - which is not a prerequisite. The result was extremely low averages on exams. Now, for the final, he came up with the idea of replacing a students lowest midterm grade with their final grade (if higher), which will screw the distribution

Let's be fair. He is not very good at lecturing but he has been trying to be helpful. The exam questions are fair(compare to 2nd semester-intro physics tests of some colleges, his exams are "easy"). I am getting a terrible grade from this class, yet I want to thank him for trying to help us to learn rather to memorize physics.

His lectures were not very helpful. I stopped attending lecture and got better grades on my exams. I relied on self-studying, office hours, and tutoring. I thought he was really helpful one-on-one. But he was a first year prof though.

Worst professor at UW-Madison.  Hands down. I hope he reads all of these comments and realizing that an average of 53% on a midterm is a complete reflection of how he teaches. A 20% got a C?! I hope to god our final grade curve is something incredible, because the vast majority is done for.

Very unorganized. You can tell he kind if tries if you go in and meet with him. However, during class he occasionally asks if people understand him.. a few people raise their hand and he seems satisfied that two people know what he's about. The exams are horrid. There is so much calculus and geometry that isn't even important to physics concepts.
Very unorganized, highly confusing. Lack of preparation. Tests DO NOT match what he teaches/what is in homework. I'm extremely dissatisfied.

He's really bad. He makes a ton of mistakes in lecture and writes illegibly on the board no matter how many people ask him to write bigger. His tests are next to impossible and are more like calculus than the physics from the text/hmwk. The class feels hopeless because his tests never reflect what you actually learn from class. I hate physics now.

You can tell he's a nice guy, but he has no experience in teaching and running a class. The tests are way too hard, and this is coming from someone who got an A in 207 and is a math major. They don't test your knowledge of the matter but test more of your in depth physics IQ. I just hope to god he curves the class by a good 30% - at least

Worst prof I've had at UW. This is the only class I've ever dropped in my life. I thought I would be ok given my AB in 207, but he frequently makes mistakes in lecture, does not give adequate prep homework, and makes exams unreasonably hard. Nice guy, but more concerned with making his class difficult than helpful. DO NOT TAKE PHYSICS WITH THIS MAN
He's terrible.

Worst professor I've had at Madison. Unprepared for lecture and unorganized. His digressions, which are many, confuse rather than clarify. Exams are difficult and homework does not prepare you for them.
